questions.text: A lady underwent vaginal hysterectomy for Carcinoma cervix. Following the surgery after her urethral catheter was removed, she complained of leaking of urine. Methylene blue dye was instilled in her bladder through her urethra, and she was given oral Phenazopyridine dye. After some time, her pads were checked and it showed yellow staining at the top most pad, while the middle or bottom pads were unstained. She is likely to have?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Ureterovaginal fistula

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula. The urine, which is being brought by ureters is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow. The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethero-vaginal fistula.
  • • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.
  • • The urine, which is being brought by ureters is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow.
  • • The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethero-vaginal fistula.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Urge Incontinence: This is a type of urinary incontinence in adults, which involves sudden compelling urges to void and results in involuntary leakage of urine Option C: Neurogenic bladder: This presents as urgency, frequency or even as continuois urinary incontience. However as there is no fistula, on the 3 swab test, there will be no staining or wettingof the swabs Option D: Urinary tract infection: This will present as frequency and burning micturition. It can also present as fever, flank pain and constitutional symptoms in pyelonephritis.
  • • Option A: Urge Incontinence: This is a type of urinary incontinence in adults, which involves sudden compelling urges to void and results in involuntary leakage of urine
  • • Option A: Urge Incontinence:
  • • Option C: Neurogenic bladder: This presents as urgency, frequency or even as continuois urinary incontience. However as there is no fistula, on the 3 swab test, there will be no staining or wettingof the swabs
  • • Option C: Neurogenic bladder:
  • • Option D: Urinary tract infection: This will present as frequency and burning micturition. It can also present as fever, flank pain and constitutional symptoms in pyelonephritis.
  • • Option D: Urinary tract infection:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 55 years old multigravida with history of frequently micturating due to coughing laughing & sneezing. The diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Stress incontinence

questions.text: Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula via continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely to happen in which of the following settings?

options.label: A
options.text: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm.

options.label: B
options.text: The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.

options.label: C
options.text: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation

options.label: D
options.text: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Occasionally, genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter. Urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small (2- to 3-mm diameter).
  • • Occasionally, genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • • Urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small (2- to 3-mm diameter).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas are unlikely to heal spontaneusly Option C: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Post Radiotherapy fistulas heal poorly Option D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: If the fistula is small, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization
  • • Option A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas are unlikely to heal spontaneusly
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Post Radiotherapy fistulas heal poorly
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: If the fistula is small, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ref: Page 608, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 608, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic tools or techniques would help identify a ureterovaginal fistula?

options.label: D
options.text: “Three-swab” or tampon test with diluted solution of methylene blue instilled (retrograde) into the bladder

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Intravenous pyelogram

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • For ureterovaginal fistulas,the investigation of choice is a CT urography as CT urography will clearly show extravasaton from the ureter and the site of injury. However since this is not there in the option and the closest option to a CT urography is an intravenus pyelogram which will also demonstrate extravasation of contrast from ureter with mild to moderate hydro-uretero nephrosis. Also it is important to remember that the pr esence of contrast in the vagina gives a typical cup and saucer sign in vesico-vaginal fistula.
  • • For ureterovaginal fistulas,the investigation of choice is a CT urography as CT urography will clearly show extravasaton from the ureter and the site of injury.
  • • However since this is not there in the option and the closest option to a CT urography is an intravenus pyelogram which will also demonstrate extravasation of contrast from ureter with mild to moderate hydro-uretero nephrosis.
  • • Also it is important to remember that the pr esence of contrast in the vagina gives a typical cup and saucer sign in vesico-vaginal fistula.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Cystourethroscopy: This is for diagnosis of vesico vaginal fistula or urethro vaginal fistula Option C: Voiding cystourethrogram: It is not useful in uretero vaginal fistulas. Evaluation of a uro genital fistula is incomplete without a functional study like a IV or CT urography as 12% of VVF patietns have concomitant uretro vaginal fistulas Option D: 3 swab test: It is not a confirmatory test. It is a clinical test when a uro-genital fistulas is suspected
  • • Option A: Cystourethroscopy: This is for diagnosis of vesico vaginal fistula or urethro vaginal fistula
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Voiding cystourethrogram: It is not useful in uretero vaginal fistulas. Evaluation of a uro genital fistula is incomplete without a functional study like a IV or CT urography as 12% of VVF patietns have concomitant uretro vaginal fistulas
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: 3 swab test: It is not a confirmatory test. It is a clinical test when a uro-genital fistulas is suspected
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The investigation of choice to diagnose a uretero vaginal fistula is a CT urography Other investigationa are Cystoscopy + Retrograde Pyelography Intra venous pyelogram MR urography
  • ➤ The investigation of choice to diagnose a uretero vaginal fistula is a CT urography
  • ➤ Other investigationa are Cystoscopy + Retrograde Pyelography Intra venous pyelogram MR urography
  • ➤ Cystoscopy + Retrograde Pyelography Intra venous pyelogram MR urography

questions.text: Your patient, who underwent hysterectomy 3 months ago, complains of urine leakage from her vagina. You suspect she has developed a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following radiologic tests is the most appropriate to order in her evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. CT urography

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed
  • • Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Intravenous pyelography: This is not the investigation of choice for a VVF now as CT urography is now widely available. The typical appearance of a VVF on an IVP is a cup and saucer appearance. Where CT is not available, IVP can be used. Option B: Voiding cystourethrography: This can be used for VVF but is not preferred as upto 12% of VVF will have a concomitant uretero vaginal fistula which can be missed. Option D: Positive pressure urethrography : IS for diagnosing urethral diverticula
  • • Option A: Intravenous pyelography: This is not the investigation of choice for a VVF now as CT urography is now widely available. The typical appearance of a VVF on an IVP is a cup and saucer appearance. Where CT is not available, IVP can be used.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option B: Voiding cystourethrography: This can be used for VVF but is not preferred as upto 12% of VVF will have a concomitant uretero vaginal fistula which can be missed.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option D: Positive pressure urethrography : IS for diagnosing urethral diverticula
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed
  • ➤ Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed
  • ➤ Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: When the patient’s history suggests an overlap in both stress and urge incontinence symptoms, which of the following terms is used?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mixed urinary incontinence

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Urinary incontinence is defined as involuntary leakage of urine. Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of urine with increases in intraabdominal pressure. Urgency urinary incontinence (previously “urge” urinary incontinence) is the involuntary leakage accompanied or immediately preceded by a perceived strong imminent need to void. A related condition, overactive bladder, describes urinary urgency with or without incontinence and usually with increased daytime urinary frequency and nocturia When both stress and urgency symptoms are present, it is called mixed urinary incontinence.
  • • Urinary incontinence is defined as involuntary leakage of urine.
  • • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of urine with increases in intraabdominal pressure.
  • • Urgency urinary incontinence (previously “urge” urinary incontinence) is the involuntary leakage accompanied or immediately preceded by a perceived strong imminent need to void. A related condition, overactive bladder, describes urinary urgency with or without incontinence and usually with increased daytime urinary frequency and nocturia
  • • When both stress and urgency symptoms are present, it is called mixed urinary incontinence.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Overflow incontinence: Overflow urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine from an overdistended bladder due to impaired detrusor contractility and/or bladder outlet obstruction. Neurologic diseases such as spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes can impair detrusor function. Bladder outlet obstruction can be caused by external compression by abdominal or pelvic masses and pelvic organ prolapse, among other causes. Option C: Complex urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology Option D: Augmented urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology
  • • Option A: Overflow incontinence: Overflow urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine from an overdistended bladder due to impaired detrusor contractility and/or bladder outlet obstruction. Neurologic diseases such as spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes can impair detrusor function. Bladder outlet obstruction can be caused by external compression by abdominal or pelvic masses and pelvic organ prolapse, among other causes.
  • • Option A:
  • • Option C: Complex urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Augmented urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Types of urinary incontinence:

questions.text: In the POP-Q system of uterine prolapse classification, how many fixed points are there?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. 6

Explanation:

  • • POP-Q is Pelvic Organ Prolapse – Quantification System. The hymen acts as the fixed point of reference. There are 6 defined fixed points for measurement in this system Anterior: Aa, Ba, C Posterior: Ap, Bp, D Three other landmarks are described: Genital hiatus (gh) Total vaginal length (tvl) Perineal body (pb) Each of these 3 measurements is measured in cm above or proximal to the hymen (negative) or below/ distal to the hymen (positive) with the plane of the hymen as zero (0)
  • • POP-Q is Pelvic Organ Prolapse – Quantification System.
  • • The hymen acts as the fixed point of reference.
  • • There are 6 defined fixed points for measurement in this system Anterior: Aa, Ba, C Posterior: Ap, Bp, D
  • • Anterior: Aa, Ba, C Posterior: Ap, Bp, D
  • • Anterior: Aa, Ba, C
  • • Posterior: Ap, Bp, D
  • • Three other landmarks are described: Genital hiatus (gh) Total vaginal length (tvl) Perineal body (pb)
  • • Genital hiatus (gh) Total vaginal length (tvl) Perineal body (pb)
  • • Genital hiatus (gh)
  • • Total vaginal length (tvl)
  • • Perineal body (pb)
  • • Each of these 3 measurements is measured in cm above or proximal to the hymen (negative) or below/ distal to the hymen (positive) with the plane of the hymen as zero (0)

questions.text: An 89-year-old lady with multiple medical co-morbidities presents with pelvic organ prolapse. She has a grade IV prolapsen (procidentia). Which of the following surgical options would be most appropriate for her?

options.label: A
options.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Colpocleisis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Colpocleisis involves closing off the vagina and is an obliterative procedure which takes a very short time to do and hence is preferred in elderly women who have multiple co-morbidites and are unfit for major surgery. The commonest type of colpocleisis is called a Le-Fort colpocleisis
  • ➤ A Colpocleisis involves closing off the vagina and is an obliterative procedure which takes a very short time to do and hence is preferred in elderly women who have multiple co-morbidites and are unfit for major surgery.
  • ➤ A Colpocleisis involves closing off the vagina and is an obliterative procedure which takes a very short time to do and hence is preferred in elderly women who have multiple co-morbidites and are unfit for major surgery.
  • ➤ The commonest type of colpocleisis is called a Le-Fort colpocleisis
  • ➤ The commonest type of colpocleisis is called a Le-Fort colpocleisis
  • ➤ Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th EDITION,( e-book) pg- 1616, 1642.
  • ➤ Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th EDITION,( e-book) pg- 1616, 1642.

questions.text: The deepest part of the perineal body if cut /damaged can lead to rectocele, cystocele and uterine prolapse. This is due to damage of which muscle?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pubococcygeus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the levator plate to sag and cause prolapse.
  • ➤ Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the levator plate to sag and cause prolapse.

questions.text: A 25y nulliparous woman presents to the OPD with a vaginal mass. She is diagnosed to have a uterine prolapse and is advised a sling surgery. All the following are sling operations for uterine prolapse except?

While performing Burch operation for stress urinary incontinence, there was significant bleeding and pooling of blood in the space of Retzius. The source of bleeding cannot be visualized. What is the next step in the management?

options.label: B
options.text: Give a generalized suture in bleeding area

options.label: C
options.text: Lift endopelvic fascia by putting fingers in vagina

questions.correct_answer: C. Lift endopelvic fascia by putting fingers in vagina
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Lift endopelvic fascia by putting fingers in vagina

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Burch colposuspension (retropubic urethropexy) involves the attachment of the fascia at the level of the bladder neck to the iliopectineal ligament (Cooper’s ligament) It is an abdominally performed surgery for stress urinary incontinence and is considered the gold standard surgical procedure for sress urinary incontinence
  • ➤ Burch colposuspension (retropubic urethropexy) involves the attachment of the fascia at the level of the bladder neck to the iliopectineal ligament (Cooper’s ligament)
  • ➤ It is an abdominally performed surgery for stress urinary incontinence and is considered the gold standard surgical procedure for sress urinary incontinence
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1061, Williams Gynecology
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1061, Williams Gynecology

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman complains of constipation and difficulty having bowel movements. She states that she often needs to use her fingers to push her vagina backward to achieve a bowel movement. Her history is otherwise unremarkable. On examination, the lower part of the posterior vaginal wall is seen to prolapse out. The cervix or the bladder does not descend down on bearing. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Posterior colporrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a cystocele (descent of bladder into the anterior vaginal wall) Posterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a rectocele (descent of rectum into the posterior vaginal wall)
  • ➤ Anterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a cystocele (descent of bladder into the anterior vaginal wall)
  • ➤ Posterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a rectocele (descent of rectum into the posterior vaginal wall)
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1093, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1093, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: A 30y G5P4L4 lady with 10 weeks of pregnancy, with third-degree uterine prolapse, is treated with?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ring pessary is the treatment of choice in patients with pregnancy and prolapse. It is required usually till the early 2 nd trimeter of gestation, after which there is generally spontaneous correction of prolapse. If a patient with uterine prolapse presents in pregnancy, surgery is NOT done and considered only after the puerperium
  • ➤ Ring pessary is the treatment of choice in patients with pregnancy and prolapse. It is required usually till the early 2 nd trimeter of gestation, after which there is generally spontaneous correction of prolapse.
  • ➤ If a patient with uterine prolapse presents in pregnancy, surgery is NOT done and considered only after the puerperium
  • ➤ ReF: Page no 539, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

Ans. B.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best surgery (gold standard) for vault prolapse is abdominal sacrocolpopexy. This can be done by laparotomy or by laparoscopy or by robotic surgery

questions.text: As shown in this image of vaginal prolapse, when the leading edge of the bulge is approximately 0.5 cm distal to the hymen, a patient is said to have which stage of prolapse?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • As per the POP-Q (pelvic organ prolapse quantification) classification, the final staging is based on the leading most point of the prolapse with respect to the hymen. There are 5 stages (Stage 0 – Stage 4) In the above question, the prolapse is stage 2 (leading most point is between 1 cm above and 1 cm below the hymen)
  • • As per the POP-Q (pelvic organ prolapse quantification) classification, the final staging is based on the leading most point of the prolapse with respect to the hymen.

  • • In the above question, the prolapse is stage 2 (leading most point is between 1 cm above and 1 cm below the hymen)

questions.text: Match the scenario with the preferred surgical intervention
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The 1 st scenario is of a woman with family probably complete (She has 3 children) but is quite young (27y). Prolapse in such a patient can be treated by Manchester repair (which involves cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments over the cervical stump) The 2 nd scenario is one of nulliparous prolapse. This can be treated with sling surgeries and nowadays, hystero-sacropexy/ cervico-sacropexy (laparoscopic or laparotomy) is done. Another procedure called cervico-pectopexy is done (the cervix is attached to the iliopectineal ligaments) The 3 rd scenario is a peri-menopausal woman with prolapse. Here Ward Mayo is preferred. This includes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpo-perineorrhaphy
  • • The 1 st scenario is of a woman with family probably complete (She has 3 children) but is quite young (27y). Prolapse in such a patient can be treated by Manchester repair (which involves cervical amputation with plication of the cardinal ligaments over the cervical stump)
  • • The 2 nd scenario is one of nulliparous prolapse. This can be treated with sling surgeries and nowadays, hystero-sacropexy/ cervico-sacropexy (laparoscopic or laparotomy) is done. Another procedure called cervico-pectopexy is done (the cervix is attached to the iliopectineal ligaments)
  • • The 3 rd scenario is a peri-menopausal woman with prolapse. Here Ward Mayo is preferred. This includes vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpo-perineorrhaphy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgeries for uterine prolapse include:
  • ➤ Surgeries for uterine prolapse include:
  • ➤ If family complete and elderly/ postmenopausal: Vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy (cystocele repair) and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (rectocele repair) If family complete and young: Manchester repair/ Fothergill repair or Shirodkar modification of Manchester If young and nulliparous: Sling surgeries or hysteropexy surgery If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis
  • ➤ If family complete and elderly/ postmenopausal: Vaginal hysterectomy with anterior colporrhaphy (cystocele repair) and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy (rectocele repair)
  • ➤ If family complete and young: Manchester repair/ Fothergill repair or Shirodkar modification of Manchester
  • ➤ If young and nulliparous: Sling surgeries or hysteropexy surgery
  • ➤ If old and unfit for major surgery: Colpocleisis
  • ➤ Ref: Page 211, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 211, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: How is a 3 rd degree prolapse differentiated from a 4 th degree prolapse (procidentia)?

options.label: A
options.text: Passing a sound through the cervix

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • As per the Shaw’s classification of utero-vaginal prolapse, there are 4 degrees of prolapse Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus Now on inspection, stage 3 and 4 will appear the same like this:
  • • As per the Shaw’s classification of utero-vaginal prolapse, there are 4 degrees of prolapse Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Stage 0 – No prolapse Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Stage 0 – No prolapse
  • • Stage I – Descent of the cervix into the vagina
  • • Stage II – Descent of the cervix up to the introitus
  • • Stage III – Descent of the cervix outside the introitus
  • • Stage IV / Procidentia – whole of the uterus is outside the introitus
  • • Now on inspection, stage 3 and 4 will appear the same like this:
  • • They are differentiated by approximating the thumb and finger of the examining hand at the introitus over the swelling If the thumb and finger approximate, this means it is a procidentia i.e. the thumb and finger are able to get above the uterine fundus If the thumb and finger don’t approximate, it is a 3 rd degree uterine prolapse
  • • They are differentiated by approximating the thumb and finger of the examining hand at the introitus over the swelling
  • • If the thumb and finger approximate, this means it is a procidentia i.e. the thumb and finger are able to get above the uterine fundus
  • • If the thumb and finger don’t approximate, it is a 3 rd degree uterine prolapse
  • • Other options
  • • Other options
  • • An ultrasound (trans-perineal or trans-vaginal) does not help in determining the degree of prolapse A uterine sound helps in differentiating between a chronic uterine inversion and a prolapse
  • • An ultrasound (trans-perineal or trans-vaginal) does not help in determining the degree of prolapse
  • • A uterine sound helps in differentiating between a chronic uterine inversion and a prolapse

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A thumb finger test helps differentiate a 3 rd degree prolapse from a 4 th degree prolapse (Procidentia)
